elements.content: The synthesis of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitor 3 is described. This complex structure contains a tetrazole modified by a chiral hemiaminal carbonate prodrug. A regioselective tin-mediated alkylation was utilized to access the N-1 alkylated tetrazole isomer, and a highly selective enzymatic hydrolysis efficiently provided the desired prodrug enantiomer. A Suzuki–Miyaura coupling was employed for the final fragment union, which was challenging due to base sensitivity of the prodrug. This route was enabled and used to manufacture multikilogram quantities of API 3 in an efficient manner.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) inhibitor 3 is described. This complex structure contains a tetrazole modified by a chiral hemiaminal carbonate prodrug. A regioselective tin-mediated alkylation was utilized to access the N-1 alkylated tetrazole isomer, and a highly selective enzymatic hydrolysis efficiently provided the desired prodrug enantiomer. A Suzuki-Miyaura coupling was employed for the final fragment union, which was challenging due to base sensitivity of the prodrug. This route was enabled and used to manufacture multikilogram quantities of API 3 in an efficient manner.

elements.content: The risk of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease (CHD) is correlated with high levels of the serum LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) biomarker. Statins such as Lipitor or Crestor are often frontline treatments when pharmaceutical intervention is required to lower LDL-C, but these agents do not always provide sufficient lowering of LDL-C. Inhibition of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) has emerged as a promising new treatment for decreasing serum LDL-C levels and reducing risk of CHD. Examples of recently approved PCSK9 inhibitors include the injectable monoclonal antibody (mAb) drugs alirocumab and evolocumab. However, discovery of a small molecule PCSK9 inhibitor with the possibility to deliver it by the more convenient oral route has lagged behind the mAbs. Previous disclosures from the Pfizer laboratories have described small molecule protein translation inhibitors of PCSK9 such as PF-06446846 (1), PF-07556769 (2), and PF-06815345 (3; ). Since PCSK9 is synthesized primarily in the liver, the mode-of-action of the aforementioned inhibitors makes them well-suited for application of a tissue-targeted delivery approach. Thus, the liver-targeted variants, 2 and 3, relied on prodrugs of parent zwitterionic tetrazoles to both enhance permeability and allow rapid carboxylesterase 1 catalyzed release and retention of the parent tetrazole in the liver. The identification and assessment of tetrazole prodrug 2 revealed a nonselective cleavage of the prodrug in both the gut and the liver. Subsequent optimization work indicated that not only the point of attachment to the tetrazole but also selection of a specific enantiomer of the prodrug were essential for the identification of a viable liver-targeted prodrug candidate 3. The synthetic challenges associated with the large-scale synthesis of 3 include the regio- and enantioselective formation of a tetrazole hemiaminal carbonate, its participation in the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling, and the handling of the base-sensitive hemiaminal carbonates. Herein, we disclose a safe and scalable route directed toward kilogram quantities of 3 to support clinical studies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The risk of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease (CHD) is correlated with high levels of the serum LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) biomarker. Statins such as Lipitor or Crestor are often frontline treatments when pharmaceutical intervention is required to lower LDL-C, but these agents do not always provide sufficient lowering of LDL-C. Inhibition of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9) has emerged as a promising new treatment for decreasing serum LDL-C levels and reducing risk of CHD. Examples of recently approved PCSK9 inhibitors include the injectable monoclonal antibody (mAb) drugs alirocumab and evolocumab. However, discovery of a small molecule PCSK9 inhibitor with the possibility to deliver it by the more convenient oral route has lagged behind the mAbs. Previous disclosures from the Pfizer laboratories have described small molecule protein translation inhibitors of PCSK9 such as PF-06446846 (1), PF-07556769 (2), and PF-06815345 (3; ). Since PCSK9 is synthesized primarily in the liver, the mode-of-action of the aforementioned inhibitors makes them well-suited for application of a tissue-targeted delivery approach. Thus, the liver-targeted variants, 2 and 3, relied on prodrugs of parent zwitterionic tetrazoles to both enhance permeability and allow rapid carboxylesterase 1 catalyzed release and retention of the parent tetrazole in the liver. The identification and assessment of tetrazole prodrug 2 revealed a nonselective cleavage of the prodrug in both the gut and the liver. Subsequent optimization work indicated that not only the point of attachment to the tetrazole but also selection of a specific enantiomer of the prodrug were essential for the identification of a viable liver-targeted prodrug candidate 3. The synthetic challenges associated with the large-scale synthesis of 3 include the regio- and enantioselective formation of a tetrazole hemiaminal carbonate, its participation in the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling, and the handling of the base-sensitive hemiaminal carbonates. Herein, we disclose a safe and scalable route directed toward kilogram quantities of 3 to support clinical studies.

elements.content: A conserved approach for the manufacture of PCSK9 inhibitors 1, 2, and 3 installed a functionalized southern fragment by coupling to the amide-containing northern fragment (4 or 5, ). For target 3, this required the bulk manufacture of prodrug modified tetrazole 6. A safe process for the manufacture of iodopyrazole 7 has been developed, allowing access to multikilogram quanitites. This material, while highly energetic (DSC onset of 201 °C, 1020 J/g), is not friction or shock sensitive, allowing for safe handling and shipment under standard conditions. At the outset, the synthesis of N-1 substituted tetrazole 6 from parent tetrazole 7 by alkylation posed a significant challenge. The regioselective N-1 alkylation of 5-substituted tetrazoles is not well-known, and the formation of the requisite hemiaminal ethyl carbonate in an enantioselective manner would make this task even more difficult.
elements.clean_text:
Initial Synthesis of Iodopyrazole Tetrazole 6 

A conserved approach for the manufacture of PCSK9 inhibitors 1, 2, and 3 installed a functionalized southern fragment by coupling to the amide-containing northern fragment (4 or 5, ). For target 3, this required the bulk manufacture of prodrug modified tetrazole 6. A safe process for the manufacture of iodopyrazole 7 has been developed, allowing access to multikilogram quanitites. This material, while highly energetic (DSC onset of 201 °C, 1020 J/g), is not friction or shock sensitive, allowing for safe handling and shipment under standard conditions. At the outset, the synthesis of N-1 substituted tetrazole 6 from parent tetrazole 7 by alkylation posed a significant challenge. The regioselective N-1 alkylation of 5-substituted tetrazoles is not well-known, and the formation of the requisite hemiaminal ethyl carbonate in an enantioselective manner would make this task even more difficult.

elements.content: Initially, alkylation of tetrazole 7 with 1-chloroethyl ethyl carbonate was performed in nine volumes of DMF at 65 °C overnight, providing a 4:1 ratio of N-2/N-1 regioisomer products. Screening experiments with various solvents and bases resulted in a slight improvement to an approximately 3:1 ratio of N-2/N-1 regioisomers. The alkylation of des-iodo-7 was also briefly explored, but the less sterically congested tetrazole did not provide any improvement in regioselectivity. For the first GMP synthesis of API, 6 was made as shown in , in which the alkylation was performed in three volumes of MeCN at reflux to reach completion in 3–5 h. ( Safety Precaution!While room temperature storage and shipment is supported by TSU data, laboratory samples of carbonate8appeared to decompose over time, possibly due to moisture. Decomposition of8can generate three moles of gas per mole of8, resulting in pressurization if stored in a sealed vessel.) Silica gel chromatography was used to separate the desired minor N-1 regioisomer 9 from the undesired major N-2 regioisomer 10, followed by preparative chiral chromatography for separation of the N-1 regioisomer enantiomers, resulting in a 12% isolated yield of enantiopure 6. Initially, 6 was isolated as a thick, viscous oil. Serendipitously, one particular sample solidified after being stored for several days on the bench, and this material was used as seed to develop a crystallization process. It was found that 6 could be readily crystallized from EtOH (1 mL/g) and allowed for the isolation of solids after chromatographic separation. Although the yield of 6 was low, the N-2 regioisomer and the undesired enantiomer of the N-1 regioisomer could be easily recovered by hydrolyzing the prodrug with aqueous NaOH. After pH adjustment, 7 could be isolated from aqueous mixtures via filtration.

elements.content: While not commercially available, the bromo and iodo analogs of carbonate 8 can be made from 8. Stability of the alkyl carbonate decreases in moving from Cl to Br to I. In fact, the iodo analog decomposed when stored for a few days at 0 °C. Despite this, improved N-1 selectivity was seen with 1-iodoethyl ethyl carbonate, giving an N-1/N-2 ratio of 45:55 at −15 °C using N,N-diisopropylethylamine in MeCN. Selectivity deteriorated at higher temperatures, and reactivity slowed at lower temperatures with no improvement in selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Improving N-1 Regioselectivity for the Tetrazole Alkylation

While not commercially available, the bromo and iodo analogs of carbonate 8 can be made from 8. Stability of the alkyl carbonate decreases in moving from Cl to Br to I. In fact, the iodo analog decomposed when stored for a few days at 0 °C. Despite this, improved N-1 selectivity was seen with 1-iodoethyl ethyl carbonate, giving an N-1/N-2 ratio of 45:55 at -15 °C using N,N-diisopropylethylamine in MeCN. Selectivity deteriorated at higher temperatures, and reactivity slowed at lower temperatures with no improvement in selectivity.

elements.content: In the literature, N-1 substituted tetrazoles are typically made from secondary amides, which, upon activation, react with azide to access the desired tetrazole. For tetrazole 9, attempts to access amide 12, the precursor to activated species thioamide 13 or imidoyl triflate 14, were unsuccessful, instead leading to dioxazinone cyclization products 15a or 15b (). Other protocols (i.e., nitrilium salt reacting with azide or [2 + 3] cycloaddition of nitrile with an alkyl azide) that use more forcing conditions were ineffective due to lability of the hemiaminal carbonate ester functionality.

elements.content: Another common protocol for obtaining N-1 substituted tetrazoles is via “exhaustive alkylation,” in which an N-2 substituted tetrazole is generated using a relatively labile substituent, and then reacted with a second electrophile to preferentially add to the N-1 site, forming a tetrazolium cation (17, ). This is followed by submitting the per-alkylated tetrazole cation salt to conditions that cleave the more labile N-2 substituent to provide the desired N-1 substituted tetrazole. Typical electrophiles were employed for the initial “alkylation” to install a tri-isopropylsilyl (TIPS), [2-(trimethylsilyl)­ethoxy]­methyl acetal (SEM), t-butyl, trityl, or para-methoxybenzyl (PMB) group. The TIPS substituted tetrazole was formed as the single N-2 regioisomer and upon alkylation with 1-bromoethyl ethyl carbonate gave a 40:60 mixture of N-1/N-2 regioisomers. While encouraging, this result was not superior to the direct reaction of 7 with 1-iodoethyl ethyl carbonate, and the mixture of regioisomers suggests that the silyl group may be labile under the reaction conditions. The SEM substituted tetrazole was formed as a 3:1 mixture of N-1/N-2 regioisomers but did not appear to react in the subsequent alkylation step. The t-Bu and trityl substituted tetrazoles were each formed as a single N-2 regioisomer; however, these substrates were unreactive in the second alkylation reaction. Protection with a PMB group resulted in a mixture of regioisomers and did undergo alkylation using 1-iodoethyl ethyl carbonate; however, upon heating, the PMB group remained intact.

elements.content: The tributyltin variant was more productive. Stannylated tetrazoles have been reported in the literature and have been shown to participate in alkylation reactions with iodomethane to yield N-1 methylated tetrazole species. Reaction of tetrazole 7 with bis-tributyltin oxide yielded stannylated tetrazole 18 (). Using flow NMR to evaluate this step, a ∼0.2 ppm shift of the proton at the 3 position of the pyrazole was observed immediately upon mixing 7 and bis-tributyltin oxide. In practice, tetrazole 7 and 0.5 equiv of bis-tributyltin oxide were mixed in a solvent (MTBE was chosen for convenience, but other solvents such as MeCN, toluene, or EtOAc could be used) and stirred until 7 had completely dissolved (note: 7 has low solubility in MTBE, so dissolution likely indicated that complexation had occurred).

elements.content: A sample of the stannylated tetrazole 18, normally obtained as a viscous oil that would solidify to a waxy solid, was crystallized from MeCN. Single crystal X-ray data showed a multidimensional array with bridging tributyltin groups between the N-1 and N-3 positions ( is a simplified representation of the crystal structure, showing three repeating subunits; note that N-1 and N-4 positions are equivalent and N-2 and N-3 positions are equivalent).

elements.content: The tributyltin modified tetrazole 18 reacted with both 1-iodoethyl ethyl carbonate and 1-bromoethyl ethyl carbonate (19) at room temperature in the absence of a base to give ∼80:20, N-1/N-2 selectivity. 1-Chloroethyl ethylcarbonate (8) reacted poorly with the stannylated tetrazole and gave low conversion. For optimization toward scale-up, 1-bromoethyl ethyl carbonate 19 was used due to superior reagent stability. ( Safety Precaution!Upon TSU evaluation at 60 °C for 24 h, 1-bromoethyl ethyl carbonate was found to generate significant pressure due to decomposition, and this decomposition event was accelerated in the presence of iron. A refrigerated sample was held for 6 months and showed no degradation by GC analysis. On the basis of this information,19was shipped and stored in glass bottles at 2–8 °C, and excess reagent was disposed of immediately.) Bromocarbonate 19 was added to the concentrated stannylated tetrazole 18, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 to 48 h. Reactions never showed complete consumption of starting material 7, reaching approximately 90% conversion. The reaction mixture was partitioned between MeCN and heptane to remove the majority of the nonpolar Bu3SnBr reaction byproduct (heptane layer), followed by the addition of aqueous KF to the MeCN phase to precipitate any remaining tin species as the poorly soluble polymeric Bu3SnF. Product 9 was crystallized from MeCN and then recrystallized from MeCN to further reduce the tin levels. The overall yield was typically 60%, and the isolated product only contained trace amounts (<0.1%) of the undesired N-2 regioisomer 10.

elements.content: To shed more light on the N-1/N-2 regioselectivity in the alkylation of the monomeric stannylated tetrazole intermediate 18, transition state calculations were performed at the DFT/B3LYP/6-31G­(d) level of theory (). The transition state for the alkylation of N-2 stannylated tetrazole at the position that leads to the N-1 regioisomer is 2.1 kcal/mol lower than that of the N-2 regioisomer, indicating the likely reaction pathway that leads to the major product. Alkylation at the adjacent position to the N–Sn bond would also lead to the N-1 regioisomer, though this transition state was found to be higher in energy.

Alkylation at the adjacent position to the N-Sn bond would also lead to the N-1 regioisomer, though this transition state was found to be higher in energy.

elements.content: Current ICH guidelines for residual tin (oral PDE = 6 mg/day) are defined for inorganic tin and are not applicable to organotin residues. Internal guidance set an allowable limit of 15 ppm organotin species for a 1 g/day dose. To prepare for early phase studies that could reach doses of 4 g/day, a target of ≤3 ppm was set. In lab pilots, the process described above resulted in 100 ppm residual organotin species. Remaining amounts would require a purge in subsequent steps to meet the target specifications.

elements.content: With a much more efficient regioselective synthesis of 9 in hand, we next sought to separate the mixture of enantiomers via enzymatic carbonate hydrolysis of the undesired N-1 ethyl enantiomer instead of a chiral chromatographic separation. Screening identified the CAL-B (Candida antarctica lipase B) enzyme as a promising lead, which hydrolyzed the undesired enantiomer to provide 6 in >98% ee (). In early optimization using a mixture of N-1 and N-2 alkylated tetrazoles (9 and 10), the enzyme was found to be highly efficient at hydrolyzing both enantiomers of the N-2 regioisomer (complete in 5 to 6 h) as well as the undesired enantiomer of 9.
elements.clean_text:
Enzymatic Resolution

With a much more efficient regioselective synthesis of 9 in hand, we next sought to separate the mixture of enantiomers via enzymatic carbonate hydrolysis of the undesired N-1 ethyl enantiomer instead of a chiral chromatographic separation. Screening identified the CAL-B (Candida antarctica lipase B) enzyme as a promising lead, which hydrolyzed the undesired enantiomer to provide 6 in >98% ee (). In early optimization using a mixture of N-1 and N-2 alkylated tetrazoles (9 and 10), the enzyme was found to be highly efficient at hydrolyzing both enantiomers of the N-2 regioisomer (complete in 5 to 6 h) as well as the undesired enantiomer of 9.

elements.content: The focus then turned to reaction optimization for scale-up by varying organic cosolvent, temperature, dilution, enzyme loading, reaction time, and impact of reaction rate based on starting material lot variability (mainly residual tin content, because at this point the N-2 regioisomer was minimized due to the optimized alkylation and crystallization from MeCN). During optimization, a cosolvent screen identified MTBE and MeCN as suitable options. MTBE was selected for further development due to ease of product isolation from the biphasic reaction mixture. However, in the presence of MTBE, the performance of the CAL-B enzyme was lower compared to the single phase reaction using MeCN. An immobilized CAL-B enzyme gave much higher performance in the MTBE/water biphasic reaction mixture. Further screening of different immobilized preparations led to Novozyme 435 as the optimal enzyme preparation. The final optimized process was run at 50 g/L using 40 wt % Novozyme 435 with four volumes of MTBE cosolvent along with 16 volumes of pH 7 phosphate buffer at 42 °C for 60 to 65 h. The extended reaction time was required to achieve higher selectivity by complete hydrolysis of the undesired isomer because of significant slowdown of the reaction as the resolution neared completion due to the decreasing concentration of the enzyme substrate (the enantiomer of 6). After workup and crystallization, yields of 42–45% were obtained on a lab scale. Due to the excellent enzyme selectivity, enhanced chiral purity could be achieved by extending reaction time, as background hydrolysis of the desired enantiomer 6 was minimal. As an added benefit, the byproduct of the resolution, tetrazole 7, was extracted into the aqueous phase and could easily be recovered by adjustment to pH 1 by the addition of HCl and isolation by filtration. The recovered 7 did not contain any tin.

An immobilized CAL-B enzyme gave much higher performance in the MTBE/water biphasic reaction mixture. Further screening of different immobilized preparations led to Novozyme 435 as the optimal enzyme preparation. The final optimized process was run at 50 g/L using 40 wt % Novozyme 435 with four volumes of MTBE cosolvent along with 16 volumes of pH 7 phosphate buffer at 42 °C for 60 to 65 h. The extended reaction time was required to achieve higher selectivity by complete hydrolysis of the undesired isomer because of significant slowdown of the reaction as the resolution neared completion due to the decreasing concentration of the enzyme substrate (the enantiomer of 6). After workup and crystallization, yields of 42-45% were obtained on a lab scale. Due to the excellent enzyme selectivity, enhanced chiral purity could be achieved by extending reaction time, as background hydrolysis of the desired enantiomer 6 was minimal. As an added benefit, the byproduct of the resolution, tetrazole 7, was extracted into the aqueous phase and could easily be recovered by adjustment to pH 1 by the addition of HCl and isolation by filtration. The recovered 7 did not contain any tin.

elements.content: The workup of the enzymatic hydrolysis reaction consisted of separation of the aqueous and organic phases followed by removal of the immobilized enzyme from the organic phase by filtration (see for crude reaction mixture prior to workup). The product was isolated by exchanging the solvent from MTBE to EtOH, and the EtOH concentrate was seeded with crystalline 6, cooled, and precipitated further by the addition of water as an antisolvent. For the scale-up runs of the enzymatic hydrolysis, the chiral purity in the crude reaction mixtures ranged from 97.3 to 100% ee, and the isolated product contained 182–388 ppm residual tin.

elements.content: For the previous PCSK9 lead compound (2, ), the key coupling between the requisite bromobenzamide 4 could be accomplished via a Negishi coupling of the corresponding iodopyrazole and bromobenzamide 4. This same approach was evaluated using iodopyrazole 6. However, upon attempting halogen–metal exchange with i-PrMgCl or activated Zn metal insertion into the carbon–iodine bond, rapid reaction with the ethyl carbonate prodrug gave exclusively ethyl ester 20 ().

Synthesis of Pinacol Boronate 5 

For the previous PCSK9 lead compound (2, ), the key coupling between the requisite bromobenzamide 4 could be accomplished via a Negishi coupling of the corresponding iodopyrazole and bromobenzamide 4. This same approach was evaluated using iodopyrazole 6. However, upon attempting halogen-metal exchange with i-PrMgCl or activated Zn metal insertion into the carbon-iodine bond, rapid reaction with the ethyl carbonate prodrug gave exclusively ethyl ester 20 ().

elements.content: The Negishi coupling was also attempted in the reverse direction. Quenching the reaction mixture after halogen–metal exchange of bromobenzamide 4 using either n-BuLi or i-PrMgCl resulted in the des-bromo product, but no desired product was formed when attempting the coupling reaction. Quenching a metalated sample into CD3OD did not show high deuterium incorporation by mass spectrometry, indicating that the lack of reactivity of metalated 4 is likely due to an internal proton quench. Direct activated Zn metal insertion into the ortho-fluoro aryl bromide was also unsuccessful.

elements.content: Since all attempts at a Negishi coupling had failed, the Suzuki conditions identified by medicinal chemistry for analog preparation were explored, requiring pinacol boronate 5 (). Amination of 2-bromo-3-chloropyridine (21) with commercially available (R)-1-Boc-3-aminopiperidine (22) via Buchwald–Hartwig amination followed by acylation with 5-fluoro-3-bromobenzoyl chloride (24) furnished the bromobenzamide 4. This was converted to pinacol boronate 5 using standard conditions.

elements.content:
With the synthesis of coupling partners 5 and 6 complete, the final challenge was the optimization of the Suzuki coupling to make API precursor 25 ().

The main challenges with this reaction were avoiding byproduct formation, including cleavage of the prodrug to give the unsubstituted tetrazole 26, homocoupling of the boronate ester to form homodimer 27, and oxidation of the boronate ester to the phenol 28. Prodrug hydrolysis was always observed at low levels and was observed at higher levels in some reactions that were run for several hours, so it was important to ensure that the coupling was not held for an extended time. Base choice was also critical to avoiding prodrug hydrolysis, and CsF was uniquely effective, while stronger bases (e.g., NaOH) resulted in more 26. Homodimer 27 was typically observed at 10–15% levels before reaction optimization and required some additional understanding to consistently control to low levels, as is described below. Phenol 28 was likely the result of peroxide- or oxygen-mediated oxidation of boronate ester 5. These three impurities did not purge well during product isolation via crystallization, so further optimization aimed to control the impurities was required.

Base choice was also critical to avoiding prodrug hydrolysis, and CsF was uniquely effective, while stronger bases (e.g., NaOH) resulted in more 26. Homodimer 27 was typically observed at 10-15% levels before reaction optimization and required some additional understanding to consistently control to low levels, as is described below. These three impurities did not purge well during product isolation via crystallization, so further optimization aimed to control the impurities was required.

elements.content: High-throughput screening was performed for the cross coupling, including six Pd0 catalysts and 18 PdII catalysts. [1,1′-Bis­(diphenylphosphino)­ferrocene] dichloropalladium­(II) (PdCl2(dppf)), [1,1′-bis­(dicyclohexylphosphino)­ferrocene] dichloropalladium­(II) (PdCl2(dcypf)), bis­(tricyclohexylphosphine) palladium(0) (Pd­(PCy3)2:), and dichloro­[bis­(dicyclohexylphosphinophenyl)­ether] palladium­(II) emerged as best catalysts, each showing high conversion and minimal side product formation. Further screening of a range of solvents resulted in selection of PdCl2(dcypf) and Pd­(PCy3)2, and optimization and initial scale-ups found best results with Pd­(PCy3)2 (5 mol %), 1.2 equiv of 6, CsF (3 equiv) in 1,4-dioxane in a 9:1 or 4:1 organic/aqueous ratio at 90 °C. In general, the Pd0 catalysts outperformed PdII precatalysts to minimize homodimer formation. However, even when the optimized conditions were employed for lab pilots, the amount of homodimer formed was variable. Further studies demonstrated that homodimer 27 formation was related to oxygen content of the reaction solution. Exposure of the catalyst to oxygen prior to addition to the reactor, incomplete degassing of the reaction mixture before catalyst addition, or exposure of the reaction mixture to atmospheric oxygen gave significant levels of homodimer.
elements.clean_text: High-throughput screening was performed for the cross coupling, including six Pd0 catalysts and 18 PdII catalysts. [1,1'-Bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene] dichloropalladium(II) (PdCl2(dppf)), [1,1'-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)ferrocene] dichloropalladium(II) (PdCl2(dcypf)), bis(tricyclohexylphosphine) palladium(0) (Pd(PCy3)2:), and dichloro[bis(dicyclohexylphosphinophenyl)ether] palladium(II) emerged as best catalysts, each showing high conversion and minimal side product formation. Further screening of a range of solvents resulted in selection of PdCl2(dcypf) and Pd(PCy3)2, and optimization and initial scale-ups found best results with Pd(PCy3)2 (5 mol %), 1.2 equiv of 6, CsF (3 equiv) in 1,4-dioxane in a 9:1 or 4:1 organic/aqueous ratio at 90 °C. In general, the Pd0 catalysts outperformed PdII precatalysts to minimize homodimer formation. However, even when the optimized conditions were employed for lab pilots, the amount of homodimer formed was variable. Further studies demonstrated that homodimer 27 formation was related to oxygen content of the reaction solution. Exposure of the catalyst to oxygen prior to addition to the reactor, incomplete degassing of the reaction mixture before catalyst addition, or exposure of the reaction mixture to atmospheric oxygen gave significant levels of homodimer.

elements.content: To better understand the relationship between the amount of homodimer formed relative to oxygen level, a headspace oxygen sensor was employed to monitor oxygen content and evaluate methods for effective degassing. Running the reaction under a nitrogen atmosphere that contained 5000 ppm of oxygen produced only 0.8% of the homodimer, so this was adopted as a targeted upper limit. Sparging nitrogen directly into the reaction solution prior to catalyst addition made it possible to achieve the target oxygen level. Also, for lab pilots, it was critical to have the catalyst weighed out in a glovebox the same day it was planned to be used. Catalyst weighed in the glovebox and then stored sealed and refrigerated would turn from white to pale green after a few days, providing a clear visual indication that the catalyst had been exposed to oxygen.

elements.content: Once a consistent nitrogen purge protocol was adopted, the reaction ran reliably well with freshly subdivided catalyst. The first kilo-scale run used 20 volumes of 9:1 1,4-dioxane/water and 5 mol % catalyst loading. Before the second kilo-scale run, dilution and catalyst loading were evaluated. The reaction could be run successfully at five volumes of 9:1 1,4-dioxane/water and the catalyst loading lowered slightly to 4 mol % to maximize batch throughput. In laboratory experiments, a further decrease of catalyst loading resulted in a longer time required to reach completion. Due to concerns of pro-drug hydrolysis to generate 26 and high confidence in purging residual Pd, the relatively high catalyst loading was deemed acceptable for this stage of development.

elements.content: For scale-up, some additional precautions were taken to ensure very low oxygen content. An oxygen sensor was placed in the vent line of the reactor, and extensive nitrogen sparging ensured that dissolved oxygen was minimized. The Pd­(PCy3)2 catalyst was ordered from the vendor in presubdivided ampules so that on-site subdivision could be avoided and exposure to atmospheric oxygen could be minimized. During scale-up, the sealed ampules were broken and the entire contents added to the tank via the hatch with a nitrogen sweep. Throughout the addition of catalyst and reagents, the maximum oxygen level observed was 1000 ppm, but after purging with nitrogen, levels from 0–10 ppm were typically observed. The reaction scaled well, reaching >99% conversion.

elements.content: The first and second kilo-scale executions of the Suzuki coupling differed in isolation of crude product 25. For the first campaign, a robust crystallization process had not yet been developed to allow isolation from the crude reaction mixture. A method was developed for chromatographic purification and removal of residual palladium (crude PF-06842115 charged as a 50:50 heptane/acetone solution on 20 w/w% SiO2 with 70:30 heptane/acetone mobile phase). Once the material was pure, crystallization from MTBE was very facile, providing 25 as an MTBE solvate. To avoid chromatography in the second run, a solvent exchange from 1,4-dioxane to 2-MeTHF followed by heptane addition allowed for direct crystallization of the product. The crystallization was challenging and required seeding. Initially isolated solids contained organic impurities and residual palladium and tin, so a rework was planned. Crude 25 was redissolved in 2-MeTHF, treated with SiliaMetS Thiol, filtered, and then solvent exchanged to MTBE (≤1.5 wt % residual 2-MeTHF) and isolated as the 25-MTBE solvate. This rework controlled the residual Sn, Pd, and undesired diastereomer of 25 at this stage of the process. If any of these three impurities was above desired levels, a second SiliaMetS Thiol treatment and/or recrystallization from MTBE could be performed to upgrade purity. The targets for impurities at this stage were met after a single recrystallization, as the isolated 25 contained 9 ppm Pd, < 2 ppm of Sn, and 0.1% of the undesired diastereomer.

elements.content: The established process for the final step used HCl as a solution in 1,4-dioxane. Enabling work was targeted at identification of a suitable alternative solvent and development of a robust crystallization of the HCl salt of 3. A 5 M solution of HCl in i-PrOH was effective, convenient, and process friendly, with the only concern being the risk of i-PrCl formed in the process. The deprotection reaction proceeded smoothly using 4 equiv of HCl when running at 50 °C for 2 h (). At the end of the reaction, the solvent was exchanged to EtOAc, while maintaining the temperature below 25 °C, and then warmed to reflux and granulated to give crystalline product.
elements.clean_text:
Deprotection and Salt Formation

The established process for the final step used HCl as a solution in 1,4-dioxane. Enabling work was targeted at identification of a suitable alternative solvent and development of a robust crystallization of the HCl salt of 3. A 5 M solution of HCl in i-PrOH was effective, convenient, and process friendly, with the only concern being the risk of i-PrCl formed in the process. The deprotection reaction proceeded smoothly using 4 equiv of HCl when running at 50 °C for 2 h (). At the end of the reaction, the solvent was exchanged to EtOAc, while maintaining the temperature below 25 °C, and then warmed to reflux and granulated to give crystalline product.

elements.content: The N-Boc deprotection reaction typically achieved >99% purity in the crude reaction mixture. The main impurities were the parent zwitterion 29 formed upon prodrug cleavage, the N-2 t-butylated tetrazole 30 (from reaction of parent zwitterion with isobutylene/t-butyl cation), and transesterification with i-PrOH to give the iso-propyl carbonate analog 31 (). Each impurity was present at <0.35% in the final isolated API. Residual i-PrCl was ≤70 ppm against a specification of <300 ppm.

elements.content: Although only a single crystalline form had been seen in laboratory pilots leading up to the first campaign API delivery, a higher energy polymorph was observed in the first scale-up campaign. The PXRD data of the higher energy polymorph very closely matched the desired crystalline form PXRD data and was not initially recognized as a different form. Upon further study, it was found that Raman spectroscopy could be used to distinguish between the forms. For the second campaign, online Raman spectroscopy was employed to indicate when conversion to the desired form was complete. This could be achieved by holding the API slurry at reflux in EtOAc for several hours, as compared to 2–3 h that had resulted in the transient, higher-energy polymorph that was observed in the first campaign.

elements.content: The overall synthesis is shown in . The first GMP campaign successfully delivered 1.4 kgA of API. The low throughput to access key coupling partner 6 was largely overcome in the second campaign by vastly improving the regioselectivity in the tetrazole alkylation using a tin-mediated alkylation. Although an enantioselective introduction of the prodrug would have been ideal, the resolution of the N-1 regioisomer enantiomers via enzymatic hydrolysis provided efficient, chromatography free access to enantiopure 6. After extensive optimization to achieve a scalable process, the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of 5 and 6 performed well. The overall yield was improved from 6% in the first campaign to 14% in the second campaign to deliver 12 kgA of API.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The overall synthesis is shown in . The first GMP campaign successfully delivered 1.4 kgA of API. The low throughput to access key coupling partner 6 was largely overcome in the second campaign by vastly improving the regioselectivity in the tetrazole alkylation using a tin-mediated alkylation. Although an enantioselective introduction of the prodrug would have been ideal, the resolution of the N-1 regioisomer enantiomers via enzymatic hydrolysis provided efficient, chromatography free access to enantiopure 6. After extensive optimization to achieve a scalable process, the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of 5 and 6 performed well. The overall yield was improved from 6% in the first campaign to 14% in the second campaign to deliver 12 kgA of API.

elements.content: All starting materials, reagents, and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Lab scale reactions were conducted under an atmosphere of nitrogen in glass reactors fitted with an internal temperature probe and overhead stirring. Large scale reactions were conducted in the Pfizer Kilo Lab facility. Compound 4 was manufactured at Wuxi. Tetrazole 7 was manufactured at Suven and Nalas. 1-Bromoethyl ethylcarbonate was manufactured at Gelest. Reaction completion was determined by reverse phase HPLC analysis on an HP-1100 using a Zorbax SB-CN column and monitored at 210 nm wavelength. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were collected on a Varian AS400. High-resolution mass spectroscopy data were collected on a Thermo LTQFT Ultra. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was collected on a Mettler Toledo DSC821e or DSC822e using high pressure gold-plated 40 μL crucibles. Tributyltin was quantified in solid samples prepared at 1 mg/mL concentrations in methanol. The instrumentation used to quantify tributyltin was a Waters H-Class UPLC equipped with a Waters ZQ single quad mass spectrometer. The MS was run in SIR (selective ion recording) mode to the 203 m/z ion (SnH2·2MeCN adduct). The mass spectrometer was able to detect to 2 ppm levels at a 1 mg/mL sample concentration. Crystal structure data collection was performed on a Bruker APEX diffractometer at −150 °C. Data collection consisted of omega and phi scans. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELX software suite in the space group P21/n . The structure was subsequently refined by the full-matrix least-squares method.
elements.clean_text:
General Information

All starting materials, reagents, and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Lab scale reactions were conducted under an atmosphere of nitrogen in glass reactors fitted with an internal temperature probe and overhead stirring. Large scale reactions were conducted in the Pfizer Kilo Lab facility. Compound 4 was manufactured at Wuxi. Tetrazole 7 was manufactured at Suven and Nalas. 1-Bromoethyl ethylcarbonate was manufactured at Gelest. Reaction completion was determined by reverse phase HPLC analysis on an HP-1100 using a Zorbax SB-CN column and monitored at 210 nm wavelength. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were collected on a Varian AS400. High-resolution mass spectroscopy data were collected on a Thermo LTQFT Ultra. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was collected on a Mettler Toledo DSC821e or DSC822e using high pressure gold-plated 40 μL crucibles. Tributyltin was quantified in solid samples prepared at 1 mg/mL concentrations in methanol. The instrumentation used to quantify tributyltin was a Waters H-Class UPLC equipped with a Waters ZQ single quad mass spectrometer. The MS was run in SIR (selective ion recording) mode to the 203 m/z ion (SnH2⋅2MeCN adduct). The mass spectrometer was able to detect to 2 ppm levels at a 1 mg/mL sample concentration. Crystal structure data collection was performed on a Bruker APEX diffractometer at -150 °C. Data collection consisted of omega and phi scans. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELX software suite in the space group P21/n . The structure was subsequently refined by the full-matrix least-squares method.

elements.content: To a 100 L reactor was added 2-MeTHF (20.0 L), 4 (4.00 kg), bis­(pinacolato)­diboron (2.86 kg, 1.2 equiv), and KOAc (2.76 kg, 3.0 equiv). The reactor was purged with nitrogen and warmed to 80 °C for 15 min, then cooled to 25 °C and sparged with nitrogen for 30 min. [1,1′-Bis­(diphenylphosphino)­ferrocene]­dichloropalladium (0.23 kg, 0.03 equiv) was added, and the resulting mixture was warmed to 80 °C for 16 h, until <1% of 4 remained by UPLC (actual result: < LOD 4). The reaction was cooled to 20 °C, water added (20 L), and the biphasic mixture stirred for 15 min and then separated. The top, organic layer was concentrated under a vacuum (maximum pot temperature 50 °C), then cooled to 20 °C and EtOAc (10.0 L), and n-heptane added (10.0 L). The resulting mixture was filtered through a Nutsche filter pretreated with silica gel (10 kg) and washed with a 1:1 mixture of EtOAc (40 L) and n-heptane (40 L). The filtrate was concentrated under a vacuum (maximum pot temperature 50 °C) to 40 L, and then SiliaMetS Thiol (1.5 kg) was charged. The slurry was warmed to 60 °C and held for 1 h, then cooled to 25 °C and filtered, washing with EtOAc (10.0 L). The combined filtrate was concentrated under a vacuum to 12 L. Next, n-heptane (40 L) was added and the solution concentrated again to 20 L. This was repeated until <1 wt % EtOAc was present by GC-HS. (For each distillation, the maximum pot temperature was 50 °C.) The reactor was warmed to 70 °C, held for 1 h, and then cooled to 0 °C over 2 h to precipitate the product. The resulting slurry was held for 4 h before the solids were isolated by filtration and rinsed with n-heptane (10 L), precooled to 0 °C. The solids were dried under nitrogen on the filter, producing 5 in 70% yield (3.22 kg) and containing 22 ppm Pd.

tert-Butyl (R)-3-(N-(3-Chloropyridin-2-yl)-3-fluoro-4-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)benzamido)piperidine-1-carboxylate (5)

To a 100 L reactor was added 2-MeTHF (20.0 L), 4 (4.00 kg), bis(pinacolato)diboron (2.86 kg, 1.2 equiv), and KOAc (2.76 kg, 3.0 equiv). The reactor was purged with nitrogen and warmed to 80 °C for 15 min, then cooled to 25 °C and sparged with nitrogen for 30 min. [1,1'-Bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene]dichloropalladium (0.23 kg, 0.03 equiv) was added, and the resulting mixture was warmed to 80 °C for 16 h, until <1% of 4 remained by UPLC (actual result: < LOD 4). The reaction was cooled to 20 °C, water added (20 L), and the biphasic mixture stirred for 15 min and then separated. The top, organic layer was concentrated under a vacuum (maximum pot temperature 50 °C), then cooled to 20 °C and EtOAc (10.0 L), and n-heptane added (10.0 L). The slurry was warmed to 60 °C and held for 1 h, then cooled to 25 °C and filtered, washing with EtOAc (10.0 L). The combined filtrate was concentrated under a vacuum to 12 L. Next, n-heptane (40 L) was added and the solution concentrated again to 20 L. This was repeated until <1 wt % EtOAc was present by GC-HS. (For each distillation, the maximum pot temperature was 50 °C.) The reactor was warmed to 70 °C, held for 1 h, and then cooled to 0 °C over 2 h to precipitate the product. The resulting slurry was held for 4 h before the solids were isolated by filtration and rinsed with n-heptane (10 L), precooled to 0 °C. Ethyl (1-(5-(4-Iodo-1-methyl-1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-pyrazol-5-yl)-1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-tetrazol-1-yl)­ethyl) Carbonate (<bold>9</bold>)

To a 200 L reactor purged with nitrogen was added MTBE (57 L) and 6 (12.0 kg), followed by MTBE (1.5 L). Bis­(tributyltin) oxide (12.7 kg, 0.50 equiv) was added, followed by MTBE (1.5 L). The resulting slurry was warmed to 50 °C to dissolve completely and then cooled to 25 °C. The solution was concentrated to a 40–44 L under a partial vacuum (maximum pot temperature of 30 °C), and then the temperature was adjusted to 25 °C. 1-Bromoethyl ethyl carbonate was charged (12.8 kg, 1.5 equiv), followed by MTBE (6 L). The reactor was purged with nitrogen and stirred until deemed complete. Analysis was performed using 1H NMR. A sample was prepared by dilution of one drop of the reaction mixture with DMSO-d 6. The areas of the peaks at 4.08 ppm (representing starting material) and 3.76 ppm (representing product) were compared. The reaction was complete when ∼15% starting material remained. MeCN was added (84 L) and the resulting solution washed with n-heptane (5 × 36 L). The combined n-heptane layers were back-extracted with MeCN (72 L). A solution of 9% aqueous KF was prepared by dissolving 2.5 kg of KF in 25 L of water. The resulting solution was added to the combined MeCN layer and stirred for 1 h, producing solid tributyltin fluoride salts. The salts were removed by filtration and the reactor and filter washed with MTBE (10 L). The combined filtrates were transferred to a 200 L reactor and layers separated. Three layers were present: a lower aqueous phase containing tin residues, a large organic layer containing product, and a small upper layer containing n-heptane and tin residues. The middle layer was retained for further processing. The middle layer was concentrated under a partial vacuum (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C) to approximately 24 L and precipitate formed. The resulting slurry was cooled to 0 °C and held for 1 h, and the solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with MeCN (12 L), precooled to 0 °C. The solids were dried on the filter under nitrogen until <1 wt % MeCN was present by GC-HS. Compound 9 was isolated as a single regioisomer (10.1 kg) in 59.5% yield and 97.8% purity (UPLC) and contained 166 ppm of Sn.

(<italic toggle="yes">S</italic>)-Ethyl (1-(5-(4-Iodo-1-methyl-1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-pyrazol-5-yl)-1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-tetrazol-1-yl)­ethyl) Carbonate (<bold>6</bold>)

A solution of 4N aqueous NaOH was prepared by combining 5.42 kg of process water and 1.44 L of 50% NaOH solution. A 200 L glass reactor was fitted with an autotitrator via FEP tubing, connected to 5 L glass bottles containing the 4N aqueous NaOH solution prepared above. Process water was added to the 200 L glass reactor (128 L), followed by KH2PO4 (0.50 kg) and K2HPO4 (1.57 kg). The solution was stirred at 25 °C for 10 min until all solids were dissolved, then warmed to 42 °C. At this point, the autotitrator was set to a target pH of 7–7.4, using the 4N NaOH solution to raise the pH if necessary. To the aqueous buffered solution (pH = 7.25), 9 (8.0 kg) was added, followed by MTBE (32 L). The biphasic solution was stirred for 10 min to allow for full dissolution, and titration, if necessary (pH = 7.34). Novozyme 435 (3.25 kg, 40 wt % wrt substrate) was added to the reactor and the biphasic mixture stirred slowly for approximately 72 h, or until approximately 1% of the undesired enantiomer was present by UPLC (actual amount of undesired enantiomer: 1.19% after 76 h). Upon completion, MTBE (24 L) was added and the aqueous layer removed and retained for recovery of 7. Additional MTBE (24 L) was added and the suspension cooled to 20 °C. The organic solution, containing some suspended, immobilized enzyme, was filtered through a PTFE filter cloth dressed with diatomaceous earth, and rinsed with MTBE (10 L). The filtrate was concentrated under a partial vacuum to 35 L (maximum pot temperature of 40 °C), then displaced with EtOH (40 L) and concentrated to 10 L (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C), containing <1% MTBE by GC-HS. The solution was cooled to 20 °C. A 100 mL aliquot was taken, and 6 (4.0 g, seed material) was added. This flask was held for 10 min and then reintroduced to the batch. The resulting thin slurry was cooled to 0 °C and held for 12 h until a thick slurry had formed. Water was added (22.4 L) over 3 h and the resulting slurry held at 0 °C for 1 h, then warmed to 25 °C. The product was isolated via filtration and rinsed with water (4 L), then dried in a vacuum oven at 40 °C for 12 h. Compound 6 was isolated as a white, granular solid in 43% yield (3.45 kg), 99.5% purity (UPLC), 98.6% enantiomeric excess, and 182 ppm of Sn. Spectroscopic data of the product were consistent with what is reported in the literature.

elements.content: A 200 L glass lined reactor was charged with 40 L of water. The reactor was sealed, purged with nitrogen, and equipped with an inline oxygen sensor on the vent line. All subsequent additions were performed in a manner to minimize exposure to oxygen. The water was sparged with nitrogen for 30 min. Upon completion, 36 L of water was drained, leaving 4 L in the reactor. 1,4-Dioxane (37 L) was charged to the tank, and the biphasic mixture was sparged with nitrogen for 30 min. CsF (6.63 kg, 3.0 equiv), 5 (8.15 kg), and 7 (5.99 kg, 1.05 equiv) were then charged, with 30 min of sparging with nitrogen after each addition. Bis­(tricyclohexylphosphine)­palladium (0.4 kg, 0.04 equiv) was charged, and the reactor was sparged with nitrogen for 15 min. The resulting solution was warmed to reflux (internal temperature = 92 °C) for 5 h until <1% 5 remained by UPLC (actual amount remaining = 0.4%), then cooled to 20 °C. A 20 wt % aqueous solution of NH4Cl was prepared by mixing 16.4 L of water with 3.9 kg of NH4Cl, and this was transferred to the reactor, rinsing with water (4 L). The resulting biphasic solution was stirred for 30 min, then 16 L of MTBE was added and stirred for 15 min and layers separated. The organic layer was concentrated under a partial vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve a batch temperature of 20 to 36 °C) to 13 L, then diluted with 2-MeTHF (41 L). The solution was filtered through a PTFE filter cloth, precoated with MgSO4 (8.0 kg, 100 wt % with respect to 5), and rinsed with 2-MeTHF (16 L). The filtrate was diluted with 2-MeTHF (41 L) and then concentrated under a partial vacuum to 13 L (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C), then diluted with 2-MeTHF (82 L) and reconcentrated to 16 L (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C). This was repeated until <1% of the 1,4-dioxane remained. The batch temperature was adjusted to 20°, and n-heptane (12.2 L) was added. Seed crystals of 25 (0.35 kg, 5 wt % with respect to 5) were added and the mixture stirred for 4 h until a slurry formed. Next, n-heptane (12 L) was added over 90 min. This suspension was held for 4 h before additional n-heptane (82 L) was added over 3 h and the slurry stirred for 4 h. The solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with n-heptane (41 L) and dried under nitrogen on the filter. Compound 25 was isolated in 94% yield (9.66 kg) with 96.0% purity (UPLC) and contained 85 ppm of Sn, 887 ppm Pd, and a 99.4:0.6 ratio of diastereomers. Spectroscopic data of the product were consistent with what is reported in the literature.

elements.content: To a 200 L Hastelloy reactor purged with nitrogen was added 2-MeTHF (95 L), crude 25 (18.9 kg), and SiliaMetS Thiol (10 kg, 50 wt %). The suspension was warmed to 60 °C for 2 h, then cooled to 25 °C. The slurry was filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE filter cloth, precoated with diatomaceous earth (1.8 kg) and rinsed with 2-MeTHF (95 L). The filtrate was transferred to a 200 L reactor and concentrated under a vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve a batch temperature of 23 to 24 °C) until 20 L remained. The concentrate was diluted with MTBE (95 L) and concentrated under a vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve batch temperature 16 to 20 °C) until 25 L remained. This step was repeated until ∼1 wt % 2-MeTHF remained by GC-HS (actual amount = 1.26 wt %), and the final volume was approximately 115 L. The solution was cooled to 20 °C, and 25 (6.0 g, 0.1 wt %) was added to seed the crystallization. The suspension was stirred for 8 h to form a thick slurry, then cooled to 0 °C and held for 2 h. The resulting solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with MTBE (38 L), precooled to 0 °C. The filter cake was dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 20 h to yield 17.9 kg of 25 as an MTBE solvate (12 wt % MTBE). The title compound was isolated in 83% yield (15.7 kgA) with 99.1% purity and contained <2 ppm of Sn, 9 ppm Pd, and a 99.9:0.1 ratio of diastereomers.

The filtrate was transferred to a 200 L reactor and concentrated under a vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve a batch temperature of 23 to 24 °C) until 20 L remained. The concentrate was diluted with MTBE (95 L) and concentrated under a vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve batch temperature 16 to 20 °C) until 25 L remained. This step was repeated until ~1 wt % 2-MeTHF remained by GC-HS (actual amount = 1.26 wt %), and the final volume was approximately 115 L. The solution was cooled to 20 °C, and 25 (6.0 g, 0.1 wt %) was added to seed the crystallization. The suspension was stirred for 8 h to form a thick slurry, then cooled to 0 °C and held for 2 h. The resulting solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with MTBE (38 L), precooled to 0 °C. The filter cake was dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 20 h to yield 17.9 kg of 25 as an MTBE solvate (12 wt % MTBE). elements.content: To a 100 L glass lined reactor was added 49 L of IPA and 25 (6.95 kg). The slurry was warmed to 67 °C to dissolve completely, then cooled to 50 °C and passed through a 10 μm polypropylene filter to a 200 L reactor equipped with a Raman probe, rinsing with IPA (4 L). Anhydrous HCl in IPA (5 to 6 N, 6.37 kg, ∼4 equiv) was added via polypropylene cartridge filter and the resulting solution warmed to 50 °C for 2 h, until <1% 25 remained by UPLC (actual result = 0.46%). The solution was concentrated to 13 L under reduced pressure (maximum pot temperature of 30 °C), then diluted with EtOAc (78 L) and concentrated again to 13 L (maximum pot temperature of 30 °C). EtOAc was added (78 L), and a sample was taken to ensure the displacement was complete. (This could be repeated until the target of <1 wt % IPA present by GC-HS was met.) The final solution was warmed to reflux for 12 h. During this time, solids precipitated and were monitored via in situ Raman spectroscopy. When the correct polymorph had formed, the slurry was cooled to 20 °C over 2 h and held for 2 h, and then solids were isolated via filtration, using 21 L of EtOAc to rinse the reactor and the filter cake. The solids were dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 8 h, until solvent levels were below 0.5 wt % by GC-HS. The HCl salt of the API, 3, was isolated in 98% yield (5.45 kg), 99.4% purity, < 2 ppm of Sn, 6 ppm Pd, and 100% of the desired diastereomer. Spectroscopic data of the product were consistent with what is reported in the literature.

cln_elements.content:
The overall synthesis is shown in . The first GMP campaign successfully delivered 1.4 kgA of API. The low throughput to access key coupling partner 6 was largely overcome in the second campaign by vastly improving the regioselectivity in the tetrazole alkylation using a tin-mediated alkylation. Although an enantioselective introduction of the prodrug would have been ideal, the resolution of the N-1 regioisomer enantiomers via enzymatic hydrolysis provided efficient, chromatography free access to enantiopure 6. After extensive optimization to achieve a scalable process, the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of 5 and 6 performed well. The overall yield was improved from 6% in the first campaign to 14% in the second campaign to deliver 12 kgA of API.

The solution was concentrated to a 40–44 L under a partial vacuum (maximum pot temperature of 30 °C), and then the temperature was adjusted to 25 °C. 1-Bromoethyl ethyl carbonate was charged (12.8 kg, 1.5 equiv), followed by MTBE (6 L). The reactor was purged with nitrogen and stirred until deemed complete. Analysis was performed using 1H NMR. A sample was prepared by dilution of one drop of the reaction mixture with DMSO-d 6. The areas of the peaks at 4.08 ppm (representing starting material) and 3.76 ppm (representing product) were compared. The reaction was complete when ∼15% starting material remained. MeCN was added (84 L) and the resulting solution washed with n-heptane (5 × 36 L). The combined n-heptane layers were back-extracted with MeCN (72 L). A solution of 9% aqueous KF was prepared by dissolving 2.5 kg of KF in 25 L of water. The resulting solution was added to the combined MeCN layer and stirred for 1 h, producing solid tributyltin fluoride salts. The salts were removed by filtration and the reactor and filter washed with MTBE (10 L). The combined filtrates were transferred to a 200 L reactor and layers separated. Three layers were present: a lower aqueous phase containing tin residues, a large organic layer containing product, and a small upper layer containing n-heptane and tin residues. The middle layer was retained for further processing. The middle layer was concentrated under a partial vacuum (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C) to approximately 24 L and precipitate formed. The resulting slurry was cooled to 0 °C and held for 1 h, and the solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with MeCN (12 L), precooled to 0 °C. The solids were dried on the filter under nitrogen until <1 wt % MeCN was present by GC-HS. A 200 L glass lined reactor was charged with 40 L of water. The reactor was sealed, purged with nitrogen, and equipped with an inline oxygen sensor on the vent line. All subsequent additions were performed in a manner to minimize exposure to oxygen. The water was sparged with nitrogen for 30 min. Upon completion, 36 L of water was drained, leaving 4 L in the reactor. 1,4-Dioxane (37 L) was charged to the tank, and the biphasic mixture was sparged with nitrogen for 30 min. CsF (6.63 kg, 3.0 equiv), 5 (8.15 kg), and 7 (5.99 kg, 1.05 equiv) were then charged, with 30 min of sparging with nitrogen after each addition. Bis­(tricyclohexylphosphine)­palladium (0.4 kg, 0.04 equiv) was charged, and the reactor was sparged with nitrogen for 15 min. The resulting solution was warmed to reflux (internal temperature = 92 °C) for 5 h until <1% 5 remained by UPLC (actual amount remaining = 0.4%), then cooled to 20 °C. A 20 wt % aqueous solution of NH4Cl was prepared by mixing 16.4 L of water with 3.9 kg of NH4Cl, and this was transferred to the reactor, rinsing with water (4 L). The resulting biphasic solution was stirred for 30 min, then 16 L of MTBE was added and stirred for 15 min and layers separated. The organic layer was concentrated under a partial vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve a batch temperature of 20 to 36 °C) to 13 L, then diluted with 2-MeTHF (41 L). The solution was filtered through a PTFE filter cloth, precoated with MgSO4 (8.0 kg, 100 wt % with respect to 5), and rinsed with 2-MeTHF (16 L). The filtrate was diluted with 2-MeTHF (41 L) and then concentrated under a partial vacuum to 13 L (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C), then diluted with 2-MeTHF (82 L) and reconcentrated to 16 L (maximum pot temperature of 50 °C). This was repeated until <1% of the 1,4-dioxane remained. The batch temperature was adjusted to 20°, and n-heptane (12.2 L) was added. Seed crystals of 25 (0.35 kg, 5 wt % with respect to 5) were added and the mixture stirred for 4 h until a slurry formed. Next, n-heptane (12 L) was added over 90 min. This suspension was held for 4 h before additional n-heptane (82 L) was added over 3 h and the slurry stirred for 4 h. The solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with n-heptane (41 L) and dried under nitrogen on the filter. Compound 25 was isolated in 94% yield (9.66 kg) with 96.0% purity (UPLC) and contained 85 ppm of Sn, 887 ppm Pd, and a 99.4:0.6 ratio of diastereomers. Spectroscopic data of the product were consistent with what is reported in the literature.

Silia<italic toggle="yes">Met</italic>S Thiol Treatment and Recrystallization of MTBE Solvate of <bold>25</bold>

To a 200 L Hastelloy reactor purged with nitrogen was added 2-MeTHF (95 L), crude 25 (18.9 kg), and SiliaMetS Thiol (10 kg, 50 wt %). The suspension was warmed to 60 °C for 2 h, then cooled to 25 °C. The slurry was filtered through a 0.45 μm PTFE filter cloth, precoated with diatomaceous earth (1.8 kg) and rinsed with 2-MeTHF (95 L). The filtrate was transferred to a 200 L reactor and concentrated under a vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve a batch temperature of 23 to 24 °C) until 20 L remained. The concentrate was diluted with MTBE (95 L) and concentrated under a vacuum (pressure was adjusted to achieve batch temperature 16 to 20 °C) until 25 L remained. This step was repeated until ∼1 wt % 2-MeTHF remained by GC-HS (actual amount = 1.26 wt %), and the final volume was approximately 115 L. The solution was cooled to 20 °C, and 25 (6.0 g, 0.1 wt %) was added to seed the crystallization. The suspension was stirred for 8 h to form a thick slurry, then cooled to 0 °C and held for 2 h. The resulting solids were isolated by filtration, rinsing with MTBE (38 L), precooled to 0 °C. The filter cake was dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 20 h to yield 17.9 kg of 25 as an MTBE solvate (12 wt % MTBE). The title compound was isolated in 83% yield (15.7 kgA) with 99.1% purity and contained <2 ppm of Sn, 9 ppm Pd, and a 99.9:0.1 ratio of diastereomers.

(<italic toggle="yes">S</italic>)-1-(5-(4-(4-((3-Chloropyridin-2-yl)­((<italic toggle="yes">R</italic>)-piperidin-3-yl)­carbamoyl)-2-fluorophenyl)-1-methyl-1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-pyrazol-5-yl)-1<italic toggle="yes">H</italic>-tetrazol-1-yl)­ethyl Ethyl Carbonate Hydrochloride (<bold>3</bold>)

To a 100 L glass lined reactor was added 49 L of IPA and 25 (6.95 kg). The slurry was warmed to 67 °C to dissolve completely, then cooled to 50 °C and passed through a 10 μm polypropylene filter to a 200 L reactor equipped with a Raman probe, rinsing with IPA (4 L). Anhydrous HCl in IPA (5 to 6 N, 6.37 kg, ∼4 equiv) was added via polypropylene cartridge filter and the resulting solution warmed to 50 °C for 2 h, until <1% 25 remained by UPLC (actual result = 0.46%). The solution was concentrated to 13 L under reduced pressure (maximum pot temperature of 30 °C), then diluted with EtOAc (78 L) and concentrated again to 13 L (maximum pot temperature of 30 °C). EtOAc was added (78 L), and a sample was taken to ensure the displacement was complete. (This could be repeated until the target of <1 wt % IPA present by GC-HS was met.) The final solution was warmed to reflux for 12 h. During this time, solids precipitated and were monitored via in situ Raman spectroscopy. When the correct polymorph had formed, the slurry was cooled to 20 °C over 2 h and held for 2 h, and then solids were isolated via filtration, using 21 L of EtOAc to rinse the reactor and the filter cake. The solids were dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 8 h, until solvent levels were below 0.5 wt % by GC-HS. The HCl salt of the API, 3, was isolated in 98% yield (5.45 kg), 99.4% purity, < 2 ppm of Sn, 6 ppm Pd, and 100% of the desired diastereomer. Spectroscopic data of the product were consistent with what is reported in the literature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The overall synthesis is shown in . The first GMP campaign successfully delivered 1.4 kgA of API. The low throughput to access key coupling partner 6 was largely overcome in the second campaign by vastly improving the regioselectivity in the tetrazole alkylation using a tin-mediated alkylation. Although an enantioselective introduction of the prodrug would have been ideal, the resolution of the N-1 regioisomer enantiomers via enzymatic hydrolysis provided efficient, chromatography free access to enantiopure 6. After extensive optimization to achieve a scalable process, the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of 5 and 6 performed well. The overall yield was improved from 6% in the first campaign to 14% in the second campaign to deliver 12 kgA of API.

cln_elements.content: A conserved approach for the manufacture of PCSK9 inhibitors 1, 2, and 3 installed a functionalized southern fragment by coupling to the amide-containing northern fragment (4 or 5, ). For target 3, this required the bulk manufacture of prodrug modified tetrazole 6. A safe process for the manufacture of iodopyrazole 7 has been developed, allowing access to multikilogram quanitites. This material, while highly energetic (DSC onset of 201 °C, 1020 J/g), is not friction or shock sensitive, allowing for safe handling and shipment under standard conditions. At the outset, the synthesis of N-1 substituted tetrazole 6 from parent tetrazole 7 by alkylation posed a significant challenge. The regioselective N-1 alkylation of 5-substituted tetrazoles is not well-known, and the formation of the requisite hemiaminal ethyl carbonate in an enantioselective manner would make this task even more difficult.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Initial Synthesis of Iodopyrazole Tetrazole 6 

A conserved approach for the manufacture of PCSK9 inhibitors 1, 2, and 3 installed a functionalized southern fragment by coupling to the amide-containing northern fragment (4 or 5, ). For target 3, this required the bulk manufacture of prodrug modified tetrazole 6. A safe process for the manufacture of iodopyrazole 7 has been developed, allowing access to multikilogram quanitites. This material, while highly energetic (DSC onset of 201 °C, 1020 J/g), is not friction or shock sensitive, allowing for safe handling and shipment under standard conditions. At the outset, the synthesis of N-1 substituted tetrazole 6 from parent tetrazole 7 by alkylation posed a significant challenge. The regioselective N-1 alkylation of 5-substituted tetrazoles is not well-known, and the formation of the requisite hemiaminal ethyl carbonate in an enantioselective manner would make this task even more difficult.
